newsitem.title: USA: Lawmakers urge Clinton to fill top FAA job.
newsitem.headline: Lawmakers urge Clinton to fill top FAA job.

text.p: Fifty lawmakers wrote to President Clinton Friday urging him to fill the top job at the Federal Aviation Administration with a committed, experienced aviation safety advocate.
"We need a firm hand at the helm of the nation's airline industry watchdog," said Rep. Peter DeFazio, a Democrat from Oregon who led the group signing the letter.
The job of FAA administrator has been vacant since late last year when David Hinson retired.
Senior administration sources said recently that Jane Garvey, former director of Boston's Logan Airport and acting head of the Federal Highway administration, would be named to the job.
A spokeswoman for DeFazio said there was no implied criticism of Garvey in the letter. "We've heard several names. We would welcome an appointment."
Congress eliminated the FAA's dual charter last year by removing the aviation promotion role and defining its principal mission as air safety.
That followed sharp criticism of the agency after the crash just over a year ago of Valujet flight 592 near Miami, killing all 110 people aboard.
"It is disturbing to us that despite this clear mandate, the FAA's record is still inconsistent, at best," the lawmakers wrote.
The FAA was criticised again this week for not moving quickly to require airlines to fit fire detection and suppression systems in cargo holds.
The ValuJet flight crashed after a fire in the cargo hold. Oxygen generators were blamed for the fire. The FAA has since banned their transport on commercial airliners.
But the head of the NTSB disclosed this week that Continental Airlines last month unknowingly carried a shipment of generators similar to those in the ValuJet accident.
